What's happening is over ~1100C (2055F) it decomposes into magnesium oxide and sulfur trioxide. The latter re-joins with any water to make sulfuric acid and perhaps any thing to turn it into a sulfide, like your steel cup. The MgO is a hopeless thing in that furnace because it won't melt until over 5000F.

It'll royally screw your lungs and eyes up, too. Not for enclosed spaces...
EDIT: You never got to that point. You 'made' anhydrous MgSO4 but you didn't decompose it... didn't think about that, that furnace can't hit the temps required, but just barely. The steel soaked up what decomposition did happen, so you didn't gas yourself. Assuming you're running propane, that's going to max out around 2400F at best and you're not optimal... that color was probably showing a touch under 2000F which is lucky for you and your equipment.

Epsom Salt (MgSO4) decomposes when heated above 1124°C forming Magnesium Oxyde (The white power you had). The SO3 gas bonds with the Water vapor from your propane flames forming sulphuric acid, and the sulfuric acid reacts with your Steel Cup. Bottom line is... you can't really melt epsom salt without it decomposing.

Nate, you're right; THIS doesn't MELT like normal... In fact, it decomposes (several times) rather than melting. Under normal atmospheric conditions, you will never be able to melt it.
Many minerals are hydrated - meaning that the metallic cation is coupled with one or more water molecules - and that the hydrated cation is integral to the crystal matrix. Heated MgSO4•7H2O decomposes to MgSO4•H2O, then subsequently decomposing to MgSO4, which finally decomposes to MgO(solid, with melting point over 5,000°F) and SO3(gas). No magnesium sulphate remains.
"The steel cup it is in is starting to fall apart....it's possible that the magnesium sulfate does something as well..." Yes, the SO3 gas is extremely corrosive and is used to make SULFURIC ACID!

Epsom salt does not melt. It decomposes, first losing water of crystallization then at 1124°C decomposes giving of SO3 gas.
